Posts.Title: MMN ChocolateLover

Posts.Content: Aug 14, 2010 09:33AM - edited Aug 14, 2010 09:36AM by Lady_Madonna *edited to add "in the supine position" I consulted with two rads oncs, the second (who I am currently receiving treatment from) has 21 years of experience and was chief resident at Memorial Sloan Kettering... Both doctors told me the prone position was most advantageous for women with large breasts because in this position the heart drops forward, toward the area being radiated.  While you're lying on your back, the heart drop toward your back, away from the area being radiated.   I am doing IMRT rads on the left side, in the supine position.

Posts.Content: Nov 13, 2010 01:59PM - edited Aug 20, 2013 06:10AM by Lady_Madonna Kellie, I know EXACTLY how you feel!!  That's what's great about being here... we can all relate.  I just recently decided that the stress of worrying about all this would probaby cause me more harm than the thing I was worrying about itself!  So I pick and choose what works in my new lifestyle.  There are many, many products I've given up and exchanged.  But after trying every single deodorant I could get my hands on I found that I could not live feeling wet and clammy every day of my life- I was miserable.  So back to my regular deodorant for me.  I won't use lip balm that isn't 100% natural and organic but I won't give up my regular (mac!) eyeshadow.  I figure a lot of lip balm gets into your mouth whereas the shadow just sits on top of your skin.  You really just have to make decisions for yourself and then be at peace.  You can't stop living or worse, drive yourself mad with micro-managing!!  Because you will go crazy (as you're noticing!!)  Think about how many women are walking around on this planet smoking, loaded up with tons of makeup and hair products, without a care in the world... and they won't get breast cancer.  There's a certain element of randomness and genetics that can't be denied.  It's not our fault.   I hope you have lots more good days and you find many wonderful friends here at bco.  Enjoy your little girl- what a blessing!  (I'm on the ladies in their 30's board and quite a few wanted to have kids and didn't get a chance before the damn cancer interrupted their lives.)   ((((Hugs)))) for you!!
Posts.Title: Parabens and Phthalates Free Products Arayasunshine69 Shanagirl

Posts.Content: Jun 18, 2010 04:38AM Lady_Madonna wrote: Hi Clare, I just clicked on your profile to read through all your previous posts so I know where you're coming from.   I'm surprised you ended up with a lumpectomy rather than a fine needle aspiration (FNA) or even a needle or core biopsy in the first place; these tests could have determined if your lumps were cancerous without disfiguring your breast  (particularly a FNA, mine took about 5 minutes in the Dr's office with no anesthetic needed and I had the results within 24 hours) In any event, I would recommend getting a job so you have your own insurance and can make your own health care decisions.  HIPPA is very serious about patient privacy; once you have your own insurance no one but you will have access to any of your health information or decisions.  All the ladies here are kind hearted and helpful- you will be surprised at how differently you look at life 20 years from now.  Enjoy being young, try not to worry and believe that your mom really does have your best interests at heart!
